data.text: Difference of Saddle Bag vs. Seat Post Mounted Rack

Saddle bag vs. seat post-mounted rack... Weight difference is obvious but functionally they seem similar - only the rack can take more weight and a variety on bags. Is there anything else I'm missing?
Need to have a fair bit of seat post showing for there to be room, right? Not all posts would do well with clamping forces required - maybe

data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: A seatpost mounted rack puts a lot more stress on the seatpost than a bag does. The load is cantilevered further out from the post so the leverage is more. A bag puts a bit more stress on the saddle but the rails of the saddle are short. A seatpost mounted rack also encourages more volume and, thus, more weight and still more leverage on the seatpost. If you need the volume of panniers, get a rack that mounts to the frame. Even without eyelets there are ways of mounting a frame rack to most any bike.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Put a Tumbleweed t-rack on and save your seatpost. Probably weighs less too.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: I had not heard of Tumbleweed racks before, just looked it up. Bontrager also make a light weight frame rack, lighter than the Tumbleweed and half the price. I much prefer the rack set up.
data.author: Mike Healy

data.text: Myself, if going with a rack, I'd get one with vertical supports, like a Tumbleweed. A rack lowers the center of gravity, wiggles around less than many saddlebags, and can accommodate more volume if needed. However, none of my bikes have have rack mounts; so to keep it simple I just went with the saddlebag. If building a rig from scratch, I'd go with a rack

data.text: Racks. Personally, it is all about the ease of organizing and packing/unpacking gear on long trips. The racks also give me the ability to carry more supplies in the event I'm riding a leg with little to no resupply options.
